importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Lebanese authorities arrested Hannibal Gaddafi in 2015, marking the beginning of his pre-trial detention linked to the al-Sadr disappearance case.
Libyan authorities formally requested Lebanon to release Hannibal Gaddafi due to his deteriorating health, citing potential cooperation in uncovering the truth about Musa al-Sadr’s disappearance.
A Lebanese court ruled on October 18, 2025, to release Hannibal Gaddafi on $11 million bail, prompting international reactions and protests from the al-Sadr family and human rights groups.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2015 to 2025 represents the decade-long pre-trial detention of Hannibal Gaddafi, during which he was held without trial and subject to international scrutiny and human rights criticism.

keyTakeAways: Hannibal Gaddafi, son of Muammar Gaddafi, was released on $11 million bail in a Lebanese court decision linked to the 1978 disappearance of Musa al-Sadr.
The case centers on allegations that Gaddafi withheld information about al-Sadr’s disappearance, a case that remains unresolved and emotionally charged in Lebanon.
The al-Sadr family and Human Rights Watch argue that the detention is unjust and lacks credible evidence, calling it a case of arbitrary imprisonment.
Libyan authorities have urged Lebanon to release Gaddafi to facilitate cooperation in uncovering the truth behind al-Sadr’s disappearance.
Gaddafi’s health deteriorated significantly, prompting a hunger strike and a formal 2023 request from Libyan prosecutors to release him.
The decision to release him has been met with criticism from his lawyer, who claims he cannot pay the bail and is under international sanctions.
The case reflects broader tensions between Lebanon and Libya over historical political and security issues, especially regarding al-Sadr’s fate.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is central to the legal and political controversy surrounding the disappearance of Musa al-Sadr in 1978, and his release on bail marks a major development in the case.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His leadership during the 1978 disappearance of Musa al-Sadr created long-standing political tensions between Libya and Lebanon, forming the basis of the allegations against Hannibal Gaddafi.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His disappearance remains a pivotal unresolved event in Lebanese history, driving decades of speculation and legal actions involving Libyan officials, including Hannibal Gaddafi.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lebanon has jurisdiction over the legal proceedings involving Hannibal Gaddafi and is central to the ongoing investigation into al-Sadr’s disappearance, including the recent bail ruling.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Lebanese court has ordered the release on $11 million bail of Hannibal Gaddafi, the son of late Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi, who has been held in pre-trial detention since 2015. The decision stems from allegations that Gaddafi withheld information about the 1978 disappearance of revered Lebanese Shia leader Musa al-Sadr during a visit to Libya. The al-Sadr family and Human Rights Watch have criticized the detention as arbitrary and unjust, while Gaddafi’s lawyer Laurent Bayon claims the bail is unattainable due to international sanctions and financial constraints. Libyan authorities have previously requested Lebanon’s cooperation in freeing Gaddafi to help uncover the truth behind al-Sadr’s disappearance, especially given Gaddafi’s deteriorating health and hunger strike. The ruling marks a pivotal moment in a decades-long political and humanitarian dispute between Lebanon and Libya over a historical event still shrouded in mystery.
title: Lebanon court orders son of late Libyan leader Gaddafi freed on $11m bail
